evidence.dc:description: Based on GTEX data, adult expression is high in the coronary artery and especially in the aortic artery. There is also a bit of expression in the left ventricle/atrial appendage. Based on NCBI data, there is strong fetal expression in the heart.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Truncus arteriosus (TA) is characterised by failure of septation of the outflow tract into aortic and pulmonary trunks and is associated with high morbidity and mortality. Although ranked among the least common congenital heart defects, TA provides an excellent model for the role of individual genes in cardiac morphogenesis as exemplified by TBX1 deficiency caused by point mutations or, more commonly, hemizygosity as part of the 22q11.2 deletion syndrome. The latter genetic lesion, however, is only observed in a proportion of patients with TA, which suggests the presence of additional disease genes.
dc:source.dc:creator: Shaheen R
dc:source.dc:title: Positional mapping of PRKD1, NRP1 and PRDM1 as novel candidate disease genes in truncus arteriosus.

evidence.rdfs:label: GTEx/NCBI expression

evidence.dc:description: The congenital heart disease, including ventricular septal defect and persistent truncus arteriosus, resemble the phenotype in humans.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Neuropilin-1 (Npn-1) is a receptor that binds multiple ligands from structurally distinct families, including secreted semaphorins (Sema) and vascular endothelial growth factors (VEGF). We generated npn-1 knockin mice, which express an altered ligand binding site variant of Npn-1, and npn-1 conditional null mice to establish the cell-type- and ligand specificity of Npn-1 function in the developing cardiovascular and nervous systems. Our results show that VEGF-Npn-1 signaling in endothelial cells is required for angiogenesis. In striking contrast, Sema-Npn-1 signaling is not essential for general vascular development but is required for axonal pathfinding by several populations of neurons in the CNS and PNS. Remarkably, both Sema-Npn-1 signaling and VEGF-Npn-1 signaling are critical for heart development. Therefore, Npn-1 is a multifunctional receptor that mediates the activities of structurally distinct ligands during development of the heart, vasculature, and nervous system.
dc:source.dc:creator: Gu C
dc:source.dc:title: Neuropilin-1 conveys semaphorin and VEGF signaling during neural and cardiovascular development.

evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse model

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Reduced length of neck; died 36 hours after birth due to hemodynamic instability
evidence.rdfs:label: A: Consang. & homozygous for p.Asp25GlyfsTer25

evidence.dc:description: Lymphoblast analysis showed that neuropilin was non-detectable in mutant cells.
Downgrading for consanguinity/homozygosity. Even though there is expression-level evidence, the GCEP did not feel that this was strong enough evidence to avoid downgrading.

dc:description: NRP1 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive congenital heart disease in 2015 (Shaheen et al., PMID: 25713110). One variant (frameshift) that has been reported in one proband with persistent truncus arteriosus in one publication (PMID: 25713110) is included in this curation. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss-of-function. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by experimental evidence (a mouse model; PMID: 12852851). In the mouse model, the mutant mice exhibit ventricular septal defect, persistent truncus arteriosus, and anomalous origin of the coronary arteries. In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Congenital Heart Disease GCEP on the meeting date 3/5/2024 (SOP Version 10).
